title: 113_s1929
content: The Act is titled the "King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act" and it amends the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 by addressing the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge Land Conveyance. The term 'Corporation' refers to the King Cove Corporation, 'Federal land' includes land within the Refuge and on Sitkinak Island, 'Governor' means the Governor of the State, and 'Map' refers to specific maps dated September 2, 2008. The term 'Non-Federal land' includes State-owned land and Corporation-owned land, with specific acreages outlined on a map. The 'Refuge' refers to the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge, and the 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of the Interior, 'State' refers to the State of Alaska, and 'Tribe' refers to the Agdaagux Tribe of King Cove, Alaska. SEC. 6402. LAND CONVEYANCE. On the date of enactment of the King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act, the Secretary shall convey to the State all right, title, and interest of the United States for constructing a single-lane gravel road between King Cove and Cold Bay, Alaska. As a condition, the State and Corporation must notify the Secretary of intent to convey non-Federal land to the United States within 15 days. The State and the Corporation must convey non-Federal land to the United States within 60 days of the enactment of the King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act. The conveyed land is exempt from Federal valuation laws. The Governor must minimize the road's impact on the Refuge and Federal land acreage required for construction. Incorporating national road safety practices is also required. To maximize use of existing roads, the King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act aims to incorporate them into the road corridor whenever possible. The King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act aims to incorporate existing roads into the road corridor whenever possible, including SEC. 6403 for King Cove Road. The King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act specifies limitations on the use of the road for health and safety purposes, with exceptions for taxis, commercial vans, and shared rides. A barrier cable is required for the road. The King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act mandates the construction of a road with a cable barrier on each side, limited to a single lane width with gravel construction and safety pullouts if necessary. Support facilities for the road cannot be located within the specified area. The King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act specifies that the road should not be located within the Refuge. Federal permits for road construction should be issued or denied within 1 year of application. After completion, any unnecessary land conveyed for the road corridor must be transferred to the United States. The Act does not amend section 1110 of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Road construction must comply with wildlife impact avoidance and wetland loss mitigation measures. The Governor of the State determines standard construction practices for road construction near the Refuge, including strategies to minimize impacts on wildlife during critical periods. These practices must be made public. The land conveyed under section 6402(a) must comply with section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to minimize wetlands loss, especially intertidal wetlands. The Governor will evaluate mitigating any impact on wetlands transferred to Federal ownership. "SEC. 6404. ADMINISTRATION OF CONVEYED LANDS." Upon completion of the land exchange under section 6402(a), the boundaries of the designated wilderness area within the Refuge will be modified to exclude Federal land conveyed to the State. The Federal land on Sitkinak Island withdrawn for Coast Guard use may be transferred to the State upon withdrawal termination. Non-Federal land conveyed to the United States will be added to the Refuge or Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge and administered according to applicable laws. Upon completion of the land exchange under section 6402(a), approximately 43,093 acres of land will be added to the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge Wilderness or the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge Wilderness. This land will be administered in accordance with the Wilderness Act and other applicable laws. The land conveyed under section 6402(a) will not be subject to section 404(c) regarding permits for dredged or fill materials. Upon completion of the land exchange under section 6402(a), the land added to the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge Wilderness or the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge Wilderness will not be subject to section 404(c) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. "SEC. 6405. FAILURE TO BEGIN ROAD CONSTRUCTION." The land conveyance for the road through the Refuge will be void if construction does not start within 7 years and is not completed within 12 years of the enactment of the King Cove All-Weather Road Corridor Act. If voided, ownership of the Federal land reverts back to the United States. The Federal land in the Izembek National Wildlife Refuge shall be managed as part of the Wilderness area. SEC. 6406. EXPIRATION OF LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY. The legislative authority for road construction expires after 7 years unless a construction permit is issued. If a permit is granted, the authority is extended for an additional 5 years. Legal challenges can also extend the deadline for obtaining a permit. The legislative authority for road construction expires after 7 years unless a construction permit is issued. If a permit is granted, the authority is extended for an additional 5 years. Legal challenges or injunctions can further extend the deadline for obtaining a permit. If the road is not constructed by the expiration of the legislative authority, the land exchange will be null and void.
